name: Netskope Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
title: Netskope Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
body:
In this article, you'll learn how to integrate Netskope’s Next Gen Secure Web Gateway (SWG) with SecurityCoach. Once the integration is complete, data provided by Netskope will be available for use in the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console. This data can be viewed in SecurityCoach reports and used to create detection rules for real-time coaching campaigns. For general information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.

Important:Netskope has now implemented Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) V3, a secure Netskope platform framework that should be used for your SecurityCoach integration. If you’ve previously integrated Netskope using the old REST API v2 configuration, please see the Set Up the Integration in Netskope article section below to configure your integration to use RBAC V3. For more information, see Netskope’s documentation.

Set Up the Integration in Netskope

To set up the integration in your Netskope console, see the sections below.

Create Your API Token

Before setting up this integration in your KSAT console, you'll need to create a Netskope API token in your Netskope console.

To create an API token for Netskope, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Netskope portal.
  2. Navigate to Settings > Administration > Administrators & Roles.
  3. Select the Roles subtab.

  4. Select the New button. A New Role window will pop up.
  5. To configure the New Role window, see the screenshots and list below:

    1. Role Name: Enter your preferred name for this role. We recommend the name "KnowBe4 API Role".
    2. Role Short Description: Enter your preferred description for this role.
    3. Events and Analytics: Select this checkbox and ensure it is enabled.
    4. Scope IT: Further down in the window, under Scope IT > Alerts, enable the View permission.
  6. Select Save to save your changes and create the new role.
  7. Navigate to Settings > Administration > Administrators & Roles.
  8. Select the Administrators subtab.

  9. Select Service Account. A New Service Account window will pop up.

  10. To configure the New Service Account window, see the screenshot and list below:

    1. Service Account Name: Enter your preferred name for the service account. We recommend "KnowBe4 Service Account".
    2. Role: Select the name of the role you created earlier in the New Role window.
    3. REST API Token: Select Generate token now with expiry and set your preferred API token expiration date. We recommend selecting 12 Months.
  11. In the top-right corner of the window, select Create to save your changes and generate the API token. A Success window will pop up.
  12. Select Copy Token to copy your API Token. Make sure to save your copied API token somewhere that you can easily access. You'll need this token when you complete the integration in the Set Up the Integration in KSAT section below.
    Warning:The API token will not be shown again after you close the Success window.

Obtain Your Tenant Name

You'll also need to obtain the tenant name from your Netskope portal URL. Typically, your tenant name will be at the beginning of the URL, and the URL will be in the following format:

<tenant-name>.goskope.<rest-of-url>

Make sure to save your tenant name to a place that you can easily access later. You'll need your tenant name to complete the integration setup in the Set Up the Integration in KSAT section below.

Set Up the Integration in KSAT

To set up the integration in your KSAT console, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations.
  2. Locate Netskope and select Configure Integration.
  3. Enter your Tenant Name and API Token in the corresponding fields.

  4. Select Authorize.

Map Your Users

After you’ve finished integrating Netskope, we recommend mapping your users through mapping rules or through a CSV file upload. For more information about user mapping, see our Map Users in SecurityCoach article.

Once you’ve successfully authorized this integration, you can manage detection rules for Netskope in the SecurityCoach > Detection Rules subtab.h. For a full list of available system detection rules for this vendor, see our System Detection Rules article.

images.alt:
This screenshot captures the **Roles** management interface within an Administration setting of a web application accessed via the URL `alliances2.goskope.com/ns#/settings/roles`.

**UI Elements and Context:**

1.  **Navigation Bar (Top):** Displays the application's logo (a multi-colored, linked-dot structure) and the current browser URL.
2.  **Left Navigation Pane (Administration):**
    *   Header: `← Administration`
    *   Active Selection (Highlighted Blue): `Administrators & Roles`
    *   Other visible links include: `Labels`, `SSO`, `IP Allowlist`, `Privacy Notice`, and `Internal Domains`.
3.  **Main Content Area:**
    *   **Header/Breadcrumb:** `Administration`
    *   **Main Title:** `Administrators & Roles`
    *   **Tab Navigation:** Two tabs are visible: `Administrators` and the currently selected tab, `Roles` (highlighted blue with an underscore). An orange-red arrow points directly to the `Roles` tab.
    *   **User Context:** Text reads: "You are logged in as **Tenant Admin**" (Tenant Admin is hyperlinked/blue text).
    *   **Filter Section:** Labeled `Filters`.
        *   Button: `Add Filter` (light blue border).
        *   Search Box: `Name ~ Search` (with a magnifying glass icon).
        *   Dropdown: `Type = Select` (with a chevron icon).
        *   Action Link: `Clear` (blue text with a chevron icon).
    *   **Action Button:** A prominent blue rectangular button labeled `New`.

This image displays the configuration interface for creating a "New Role" within a security platform, specifically focusing on defining role metadata and permissions.

**UI Structure and Data Entry:**

1.  **Header and Actions:** The page title is "New Role." A primary action button, "Save," and a close (X) icon are located in the top right corner.
2.  **Role Definition Fields:**
    *   (a) **Role Name:** Input field containing the text "KnowBe4 API Role."
    *   (b) **Role Short Description:** Input field containing the text "KnowBe4 API Role for SCH."
3.  **Tab Interface:** Two primary configuration tabs are visible: "Permissions" (currently selected and highlighted) and "IP Allowlist."
4.  **Instructions:** Introductory text states: "Select the functional areas for this role and the relevant permissions will be automatically enabled. You can then further fine-tune the permissions if desired."

**Permissions Grid:**

The lower half of the interface displays a grid of functional permission cards, each featuring a checkbox for selection.

*   **Selected Permission:** Only the **"Events and Analytics"** card is checked. This card includes the descriptor: "Review events and alerts and generate reports." A red 'C' marker is positioned next to the title.
*   **Unselected Permissions (with specific sub-settings noted):**
    *   **Administration:** "Manage users and roles with same or less privileges."
    *   **Network:** "Network."
    *   **Access Control:** "Control the access to the internet." Sub-selections (all checked) include: Cloud App, Web, Firewall, and Private App.
    *   **DLP (Data Loss Prevention):** "Protect sensitive data." Sub-selections (all checked) include: Real-time, Endpoint, and Api-enabled.
    *   **Threat Protection:** "Prevent malware and malsites." Sub-selections (all checked) include: Real-time and Api-enabled.
    *   **Behavioral Analytics:** "Detect anomalous user activities."
    *   **Security Posture:** "Monitor the configurations." Sub-selections (all checked) include: Data and Application.
    *   **Risk Insights:** "Discover risks in existing logs."

This image displays a configuration panel titled **"New Role"** used for assigning permissions across various features in a system console.

The UI is structured as a two-column list detailing Feature/Scope (left column) and granular Access Levels (right column).

**UI Structure and Elements:**

1.  **Access Levels:** For most features, permissions are managed via a mutually exclusive group of four radio buttons: **None**, **View**, **Manage**, and **Manage And Apply**. The **Manage** and **Manage And Apply** options are typically rendered in a lighter, grayed-out state, suggesting they are disabled or unavailable by default.
2.  **Grouping:** Permissions are organized hierarchically. Parent categories (**Reporting** and **Skope IT**) are listed, followed by sub-features (e.g., **Alerts**, **Application Events**). The parent categories display the permission levels as selectable text links rather than radio buttons.

**Data and State Analysis:**

*   **Default State:** The majority of features, including **Network Steering, NPA, Settings, Tenant Overview, User, Alerts, Application Events, Netskope UI Console, Network Events,** and **Page Events**, are set to the default permission level of **None** (indicated by a selected blue radio button).
*   **Active Selection:** Under the **Skope IT** grouping, the **Alerts** sub-feature is actively set to **View**.
*   **Parent Status:** The parent groups **Reporting** and **Skope IT** are currently set to **None**.
*   **Highlighting:** The row corresponding to **Page Events** has a light blue background shading, indicating it is currently selected or focused.
*   **Annotation:** A red circular marker containing the letter 'd' overlays the UI near the "Skope IT > Alerts" row, pointing toward the selected "View" option.

This image displays a segment of a web application's user interface, specifically an **Administration** section focused on user management.

**Context and Navigation (Left Sidebar):**

*   **Logo:** A proprietary, multicolored (orange, gray, blue) logo is visible at the top left.
*   **Breadcrumb/Back Link:** An entry labeled `← Administration` indicates the current section is nested under a main administration view.
*   **Primary Navigation:** The currently active link is highlighted in blue: `Administrators & Roles`.
*   **Secondary Navigation (Visible):** Additional options under Administration include `Labels`, `SSO` (Single Sign-On), and `IP Allowlist`.

**Main Content Area (Right):**

*   **Page Title Hierarchy:** A minor heading reads `Administration` followed by the main page title: `Administrators & Roles`.
*   **Tab Navigation:** Two prominent tabs separate content:
    *   `Administrators` (Currently active, highlighted by a blue text and an underline, pointed to by a red arrow).
    *   `Roles` (Inactive).

**Filtering and Action Bar:**

*   **Filters Section:** Labeled `Filters`, this area contains controls for refining the list content:
    *   `Add Filter` button.
    *   Search input labeled `Name ~ Search`.
    *   Dropdown menu labeled `Role: Select`.
    *   `Clear` action link with a dropdown chevron.
*   **Action and Status Bar (Bottom):**
    *   Primary action button: `Invite` (dark blue button with a dropdown chevron).
    *   Secondary action button: `Service Account` (white button).
    *   Status indicator: `101 Found`, indicating the total count of administrators matching the current view/filters.

This screen capture displays the administrative interface for user and role management.

**Context and Navigation:**
The current view is **Administrators & Roles**, highlighted in the left navigation sidebar under the overarching **Administration** section. The page title is **Administrators & Roles**.

**Tabbed Content:**
The main content area utilizes tabbed navigation. The **Administrators** tab is currently active (indicated by a blue underline), while the **Roles** tab is inactive.

**Filter Controls:**
A filter bar is present, labeled **Filters**, containing the following interactive elements:
1.  **Add Filter** button.
2.  Text input field for searching by name: **Name ~ Search**.
3.  Dropdown selector for filtering by role: **Role: Select**.
4.  Action link for filter removal: **Clear**.

**Action and Status Bar:**
Located beneath the filters are the primary actions and status indicators:
1.  Primary action button: **Invite** (includes a dropdown chevron).
2.  Secondary action button: **Service Account**.
3.  Result count text: **101 Found**.

This image displays a modal dialog titled **"New Service Account"**.

**Overall Context:** The dialog facilitates the creation of a new service account, requiring configuration of name, role, and API token generation settings. In the top right corner, there is a blue **"Create"** button and a standard 'x' close icon.

**Configurable Fields (top to bottom):**

1.  **Service Account Name (labeled 'a'):** An input field currently populated with the text: **"KnowBe4 Service Account"**.
2.  **Role (labeled 'b'):** A dropdown selector showing the currently selected role: **"KnowBe4 API Role"**.
3.  **REST API Authentication Methods:** Below this heading, there is a single selected button: **"API Key"** (rendered in blue).
4.  **REST API Token (labeled 'c'):** This section uses two radio buttons for token generation options:
    *   The first option is selected: **"Generate token now with expiry"**. This option exposes two sub-fields: an input box set to **"12"** and a dropdown set to **"Month(s)"**.
    *   The second option is unselected: **"I will generate the token later"**.

images.context: /strong> and API Token in the corresponding fields.

images.alt:
This screen details the **Netskope User Mapping** configuration interface.

**Context and Navigation:**
*   The page header explains the function: mapping users via configuration rules or CSV upload to link endpoint events to specific users. A hyperlink directs to the *Mapping Users in SecurityCoach* article.
*   The interface uses a tabbed layout: **Mapping Rules (Recommended)** is the active tab, and **CSV File Upload** is the inactive option.

**Mapping Rules Configuration:**
*   The active section, titled **Configure Mapping Rules**, explains that this is the recommended method for mapping users to KMSAT user data fields.
*   A single mapping rule definition is displayed, consisting of four elements:
    1.  Source Vendor Field (Netskope): The static value **Hostname**.
    2.  Operator: **is**.
    3.  Target User Field (Knowbe4 User Data Field): A dropdown select box showing the placeholder **Select option**.
    4.  Rule Action: A button labeled **Add Field** (to add criteria to the current rule).
*   A link labeled **Add Another Rule** is available to create a new, separate mapping condition.

**Action Buttons:**
*   **Save:** Primary action button (solid blue).
*   **Delete Integration:** Secondary action button (red bordered text).
